Didn't see much wildlife, but folks said it was too popular with humans! The L.L.Bean shuttles are a welcome necessity to save you from walking too far to get to trail heads.

Cliché as it sounds, this place is just another spot of heaven on Earth - and God knows we need those! With crystal clear ponds, mountain ranges that leave you mesmerized, and sea-air that leaves you rejuvenated, it's hard not to fall in love with this place!

This is the reason we came to Bar Harbor - Acadia! The park is incredible! In its own way, rivals other National parks in the US.When you see visitors from other countries, you know that this park is both unique and very special.If you only have the day to tour, go early, preferably during the week, and stop by at least three places: Sand Beach, Jordan pond and of course Cadillac Mountain.To get to the first two, take the park loop road. To Cadillac Mountain, Cadillac summit road. You will not be disappointed!
We really enjoyed our time in Acadia National Park. Many great views and overlooks, picnic areas, etc.
The 27 mile look has amazing coastal view. We did several challenging hikes, drove up to Cadillac Mountain for sunset, ate popovers at Jordan Pond and more!
review_title: Can't believe it took me this long to get to Acadia!

review_body: So many things to do at the park. The trails are kept up beautifully. Jordan Pond was very easygoing on one side then the other side you are crawling over boulders and walking on planks. Might not be for everyone. Some were saying they just do the one side. Cadillac Mountain was at the top of the highest mountain in the park. So many things to do here. Family friendly on some of the hikes. Sandy Beach was another great stop.

This is a lovely park, with breathtaking views, especially along the shore loop! We are unable to hike the trails, but there are enough opportunities for enjoyment . We ate at Jordan’s Pond...fabulous! But make sure you have reservations in advance. The carriage rides provide a unique look into the history of the park and relaxing as well.
review_title: First timer...wish I had gone sooner!

review_body: Arrived on a cruise ship for one day, went to the Village Green to obtain or membership for the National Park which was $15 each, obtained a map with the routes that the buses take,so easy a hop on hop off system,every bus stop gives a timetable with the next couple of buses due to arrive. We started off leaving the Village Green on 3 then changed to 4 and finally returned to the Village Green on a 5, the views were spectacular, can,t recommend enough.
review_title: Must visit if in Bar Harbour

review_body: Our time was too short, but we hiked Cadillac Mountain, and did two other short hikes with friends who live there. We did a coastal hike and made it out too Schoodic Point too. BEAUTIFUL part of the country. Weather was great in early September. Enjoyed everywhere we ate, and enjoyed doing a little shopping in Southwest harbor.
review_title: Will be returning! So much to see and do

review_body: Lots to visit and do here for any person whether extremely fit or looking to do a driving/vista tour. I was traveling with a torn meniscus and was still able to see many great vantage points without having to walk far or on rocky trails. Crowds were very manageable - traveled there in September. Good variety of restaurants in and around town. Recommend the water trip out of Northeast Harbor - Sea Princess. Very informative!
Truly a National Treasure, magnificent beauty of untouched nature. The park is simply one of a kind!
Incredible vistas, great hiking and great value, a vehicle pass was only $30 for a week of access. A must see! The view from Cadillac Mtn is breathtaking.

This park is so beautiful--the opportunities to get out and enjoy nature are all around you. The trails are fun and were not crowded at all like Grand Canyon n.p. Signage is good for directions. We saw a beautiful sunset on top of Cadillac Mountain and had popovers at the Jordan House. Huffing away I made it to the top of Bubble Rock trail. We couldn't do Thunder Hole because of the timing of tides. Otter Point was wild and had gorgeous rocks. The park is glorious!!!
review_title: beautiful peace of nature in Maine

review_body: We spent a few days exploring the park with a friend from the area. We made multiple hikes and have left postings on individual stops. Having a local guide was a major plus, however there are numerous resources, guidebooks, TA reviews! and National Park signs that make this a very easy place to enjoy. A true National Treasure and one of the highlights of the East Coast National Park system. Helpful Tips:- Buy a parking pass in advance- Bring Water!- Restrooms are found throughout the park, bring wipes- We found the park to be very dog friendly
Make sure you visit Acadia..check out thunder hole..Jordon Pond..take the oneway perimeter loop road..stop often..walk some and take lots of photos

I have been wanting to go to this National Park for years. I was amazed at how many acres it is and the diverse environments within the park. The hiking trails are the best I have ever experienced. You take away the importance of preserving nature and a renewed sense of peace and tranquility
Acadia is a beautiful park with several features that you don't want to miss. The view from Cadillac Mountain is breathtaking. They have hiking trails for all levels of hikers.

Schoodic peninsula is breathtaking. We stayed in Allbee’s Shorehouse cottages just steps from the water and hiked in the park. The rocky shorelines and lobster boats in the water made for beautiful sunsets!

Acadia National Park is a gem. With 2 locations, one on Mt. Desert Island and another part on the nearby Schoodic Peninsula, and many small towns nearby with additional facilities and activities, there is something for everyone. On Mt. Desert Island, we especially liked the Ocean Walk, Ship Head Trail, the Carriage Roads and Jordan Pond. The Schoodic Peninsula is much less visited, but has gorgeous views.
review_title: Beautiful scenery and lots of things to do

review_body: We had just one day to spend in Acadia and it wasn't nearly enough. There is stunning beauty everywhere you look! Hikes that range from easy to expert and a tenderfoot can even see a lot of the comfort of their car. I will be going back. The steps to the visitor's center are a climb but worth the effort for the movie and the info the rangers can give you. Definitely a bucket list destination.

We visited on a very misty day so the best sights were not visible - however what we did see was really lovely. There is a very nice restaurant at Jordan Pond with a lovely gift shop. Only down side, out in the park the toilet facilities are pretty grim - well worth a visit.
Took a 3 hour trolley tour of the park. Got some great background information as well as a chance to see some of the breathtaking scenery. It was a great way to experience the park.

Something for every level of fitness. Tons of driving options, hiking and tours available. This park is a national treasure. We were there just as the leaves began to turn and enjoyed the splashes of color. Don't miss the drive up to the top of Cadillac Mountain for the most spectacular views. Check in at the Visitors Center for your park pass and helpful tips from the rangers.
This is a beautiful park to drive through just outside of downtown Bar Harbor. Great views of the ocean and rocky cliffs.

From the park entrance to the top of Cadillac Mountain-it was amazing. Mother Nature was having a great day when she created this area. From woods to rocky shore line. Check out every overlook, every view is different. Plan a full afternoon for the drive. We brought along a picnic lunch. Sat and ate watching wild turkeys.

We often travel in September after Labor Day when most kids are in school, but before the leaf peepers are out. That strategy didn't work for avoiding crowds in Acadia. We were able to get into the Hulls Cove Visitor Center, but it was crowded. Tried driving up Cadillac Mountain, but traffic was bumper to bumper near the top. We couldn't find a parking space and never got out of the car. On the way down, we saw that park rangers had just closed the road going up the mountain. The next day we tried going to the nature center - no parking. And Thunder Hole was just crawling with people. The parts of the park that we were able to see were wonderful.
Beautiful park. Clean and great walking paths. Could see forever from the top of the mountain and was stunning.

Sadly we only had one day to explore, which is clearly not enough time as this National Park has so much to see and do. We decided to get recommendations from the visitor centre and covered the main areas. You are able to drive around the Park which certainly saves some time getting to various locations. Stunning views along the way too. First stop was a drive to the top of Cadillac Mountain - awesome views at the top and well worth the trip - we then headed down and found a nice 3 mile loop trail to do - it was a bit tricky in places but really satisfying and some fantastic views of the ocean along the way. Love that the Park is doggy friendly too - wish we had our doggy with us. So much fun for them! Definitely want to come back and spend more time here.
review_title: Wish We Had Longer - Loved It

review_body: We were in and out of Acadia National Park for 4 days. You can drive around (or take the shuttles) and stop to see the amazing views on the many turn-outs. It was foggy often when we were there but still beautiful.
We loved it here. Great park loop drive, amazing hikes with awesome views. but it was still very busy even in September.
review_title: Great park, but crowded even in September.

review_body: We were surprised at how easy it was to get around. we caught the bus at the square in bar harbor and road into the park, getting on and off different buses, changing buses to change the direction we were going. Always easy to get on and never had to wait long. Did some hikes and just really enjoyed ourselves.
This has to be one of the most beautiful parks in America. There are great hiking trails and is the only place to see fijords in the US. It is truly a magical place!

Although we battled fog for three days we loved the park. We had to make two trips up Cadillac Mountain to get a view and we did. The loop road trip was wonderful. This was fall so we really didn't spend any time at sand beach but it looked great. We had a very nice visit at the wild gardens and nature center with a one mile walk on the board walk, Missed Jordan lake Anne people raved about it and the carriage ride. We enjoyed the park from the nature tour boat out of bar harbor. Viewing the shore line is better from a boat
Great place to come any time of the year one of the nicest parks on the east coast you could spend days here.

We were fortunate to have bright sunny days during our September visit, with only a little morning fog, so the views from Cadillac, Mt. Acadia, Beech Mountain, and Schoodic Point were all top notch. We have no quibble with the various sites and apps that rate the day hikes; as one local put it, "they're all good -- enjoy the ones you choose and don't worry about the ones you miss." That said, we made a point of getting up and out early, and looking for less busy trails. For us, a day hiking on Schoodic Peninsula was a day exquisitely well spent. We also came to understand why people bring camp chairs and just watch the tide roll in. What a show!
review_title: Beautiful in September and not as crowded

review_body: The morning sunrise was beautiful. Seeing all the people there watching the sun come up on top of this hill was pretty cool. Cold and early. I definitely like the sunset at Key West better but sill this was nice, glad I did it. Wouldn't do it again. Signage in this expensive national park is moderate to poor, bathrooms are the visitors center are inside and it doesn't open till 8 so if you show up at 5 for the sunrise event don't go to the visitor's center. I know this park is listed as one of the top national parks I don't know why. Saw racoons and turkeys. We were lucky with good weather and great visibility. One person up at the morning sunrise event said this was his 3rd this week and the first with good weather conditions. At the top of the mountain the view of Bar Harbor is nice but you are so far away it is mostly dots on the camera. We visited Mt Battie two days ago. I think the views and pictures were better the admission was $12 for two including a car, at Acadia the admission is $30 for the car and $15 for each person - $60 total. For that amount of money I'd expect good signage and bathrooms open during big demand periods.
One of the coolest places. You defiantly need an entire day here. And a lot of it is drivable. U can hike as much or as little as u want. We will be back bc we didn’t have enough time

You must see as much of this National Park that you can when on Mt. Desert Island! The park loop road is worth the drive but if you hike at all, get on those trails, the views are spectacular! They are a bit difficult, but if you are in shape it is worth the hike.

This is a must see attraction when in the area. THere is not much around except for Bar Harbor that is about 3 blocks long but it is fantastic views and trails.Great food in the area and beautiful sights.

So, if you are looking for picture perfect green and water, you've hit the jackpot.If you are more into nature amazing creations, not it.As always, started at the visitor's center. Have entered through Hulls Cove.You park and need to go upstairs to the place itself in order to get a park permit, if you are not holding an annual one.Nice and smiley ranger was there, but the most unhelpful one I have encountered till today.The first thing you should know about the park, is that the trails are entwined into one another and you can make short ones, or longer as you see fit, which is awesome and this most important detail was known to me only when I was actually trekking.As for the list of trails, it isn't freely given with the map like other parks, you have to purchase it. I don't know what's on it, since I have relied on "All Trails Pro" which in hindsight, wasn't very useful either.You can see in the pics an example to how the trails are built.As for Camping, I went to the closer site, Blackwoods Campground, which is reviewed separately.First day I have parked in Sand Beach and went on the Ocean Path, which is more of a stroll, with niches to get very nice views of the ocean and Sand Beach, finished at Otter Cliffs and went back to the Gorham Mountain trailhead.At this point you can see how some trails can be combined.I have made the trail into a loop, that landed me back close to Sand Beach where my car was parked.Just follow the signs you want. You can't really get lost.Most of the trail is rocky and I would categorize it as moderate to easy. Back to Sand Beach and down the stairs to Great Head Trail.You cross the beach and there's a small U turn at the Beehive lake.You can loop that too. The way up is a little bit more challenging, the way down if you loop it, is easy.All the trails took me about 5 hours.Second day Jordan Pond.Take a right after a pretty boring mile and you have interesting trails - Bubble Rock, Eagle Lake. Uphill, some rocky. The north Bubble Summit is beautiful.Eagle lake not as much.The trails don't loop and I came out from the point I have entered.Then about 2 more miles back to the parking lot, around the pond.This way is a bit more challenging if you are just looking for a stroll.This has taken me about 4 hours and added up to about 7 miles.***wear proper shoes for Trekking***if you have T-mobile, there's no internet connection. It connects to AT&T and it's calls only. Highly recommend a drive through the island with the car.The park boundaries are blurred, so there's food, drinks and everything you want, just a little drive away. This is off season, so accommodation is easy to find in all price ranges.Trenton has a very cozy picnic area, with toilets, picnic table and a nice view.Have Fun
review_title: Not my top choice for national parks, but still something to be said

review_body: This, to me, was a very small, urbanized national park. I really liked the busses inside the park. I'd also say this has to be the most dog friendly national park I have been to. The only negative is this park is also almost completely surrounded by houses, and it makes it hard to feel isolated, and it's just sad for the wildlife, they can't really come and go freely.I'd say if you want a vacation with your dog, with great restaurants, little shops, lots of history, and short hikes, this is the park for you.
So I live here but visit the park often .. it’s aleays beautiful breathtaking.. if you visit please stay on the trails so the park stays beautiful and you stay safe.
So many things to do! Hiking, biking, kayaking. BEAUTIFUL! Would like to go back and spend more time doing other things.
review_title: AMAZING! Wish we had more time

review_body: First time visitors. Can't wait to come back! We stayed at an Airbnb and can't wait to come back to experience more of what the park and surroundings have to offer.

My husband and I enjoyed every minute and every vista of this spectular place. My recommendation is to utilize the bus system they have in the park. Let them do the driving so you can enjoy more of the park. Parking spaces are also a premium inside the park. My favorite memory is stopping at Sand Beach and then walking the trial to Thunder Roll. It’s about two miles and easy. If you are a picture taker like I am, it might take you awhile. Breathtaking views, It will not disappoint.
We visited the park as part of a shore excursion , the scenic ride to the top of Cadillac mountain was wonderful and the tour around the park was beautiful.

Wonderful drive up to the top and greeted with amazing views of Bar Harbor and MDI. Took a short walk around the hiking trails at the top but was concerned we might get a ticket. Apparently you are supposed to go to the Visitor Center and pick up a placard to show you paid. Never saw any signs and unlike all the other Nat'l Parks, we did not see a entrance booth to show Senior Pass. Go figure?

September is a spectacular time to visit Acadia! The weather was mild and the foliage was just starting to turn colors. The free shuttle bus is a wonderful way to get around. We stopped at all the main natural features and enjoying the immense variety. One full day was not enough for sure.

This is a gorgeous park with vistas that are beyond words. It would take several days to experience even a fraction of its vastness. Unfortunately crowds of people are very close to ruining the splendor. The park service recommends taking the free bus. Great idea. Even in the “off season”there are very few parking spaces. You will find yourself spending most of you time circling the lot in search of a spot. Take food and water with you. Once you pass the gates there is nowhere to buy anything except Jordan Pond and very limited parking there. Lots of people so plan ahead.

My last visit to Acadia National Park was 20 years ago, there were many improvements made by the park service on trails. A free shuttle bus from the visitors center takes you to various highlights in the park and reduces the car traffic and exhaust. Tickets are $30 and good for a week in the park The park loop road is about 30 miles. Highlights you should see are: Thunder hole, popovers at Jordans pond restaurant at the Bubbles, otter creek,Cadillac mountain and so much more. Just go!

We got up early in the morning to beat the rush of massive people that decend upon this beautiful Nat'l park. We'd seen on the news how it gets so crowded and there's no parking, so we looked into taking a tour bus or shuttle, but in the end, we decided to drive and go in early. We did hit some fog which spoiled some views, but it began to lift and we seen plenty of the forest. Stopped at Sand Beach and Thunder Hole. It was a beautiful drive through the park that early foggy morning.

Acadia Park is a gem for all to experience and see! The scenery is beautiful and there is so much to view. We enjoyed Thunder Hole and were fortunate to hear it boom! You can see the park in a day but would recommend taking a couple of days to experience all of the Park.

Three cheers to LL Bean. They help sponsor a great network of propane powered buses to get you in and around the park in the bar harbor out to the little airport and associated cities. No need to Rent-A-Car very timely service and comfortable. Great lobster is out by the airPort, wonderful shops in the village. Rent bikes from Bar Harbor bike rentals and ride the 40 miles of carriage built by the Rockefellers! Easy grade somewhere around 4%, get away from the crowds and see wonderful glacial lakes rock formations and coniferous forest.
review_title: Great biking trails on the carriage paths

review_body: Having been to a number of National Parks, throughout the US, this is one of our favorites, exceeded only by Yellowstone. This combines mountains, the sea, rocky shorelines, great interior trails, mountain climbing, and amazing ‘carriage roads’ for biking without ever having to see a car.

We would recommend doing the loop twice. Once at low tide and once at high tide. Totally different perspective between the two.The Hull Visitor Center was located 52 steps up. Strange to see a visitor center so far from the parking lot and with so many stairs. Not sure what they were thinking when they designed that :(
review_title: Visit during low tide & high tide

review_body: Where else can you sit on the beach and have a picnic lunch dipping your toes into the Atlantic Ocean, then turn around and climb the highest peak on the Eastern Seaboard.

We spent a week on MDI and never left the island! We were in Acadia each day. There's so much to see and do. The hiking/walking paths, Jordan Pond, Sand Beach, Thunder Hole, the summit of Cadillac Mountain are just a few things to see and do. We drove the island each day, searching the small villages and towns for things to do and see. We found quaint shoppes and family owned restaurants. Take time to stop, pull off the road and explore!
We visited Bar Harbour and Acadia from a cruise ship. Spending time in Acadia is a must. It is such a beautiful area.
If you ever get to main, you have to visit Cadillac Mountain. The drive is well worth it. The view from the top of the mountain is breathtaking.

We stopped here for lunch and weren't disappointed. The best seafood chowder I had on my entire trip. Would have liked to have hiked the 3.2 miles around the pond, but that will have to wait for a future visit.
Stunning 360 views from top of Cadillac Mountain and stargazing at night. Never seen so many stars and the Milky Way so vividly!

It is easy to drive the Park loop in a day and you can see the various sights along the way. The park is in the middle of the island, surrounded by little villages and bays along the shoreline. It gets crowded in the summer, so give yourself time.

Cadillac Mountain View’s were stunning. The park is very nice. The roads were a little arduous due to road work. Sand beach was a great stop; as was thunder hole. Well worth the $30 fee for our vehicle. The pass is good for 7 days. Sunset from Cadillac was very nice; but a little underwhelming. We should have done the sunrise. Oh well.....next time.
If I visit again I would avoid trolly tour and drive my own car. The park is very nice and views excellent. The tour guide was very knowledgeable, but too many grumpy seniors.

Acadia is a fantastic place to visit (five rating). Unfortunately, everyone seems to found that out and finding parking places can be very challenging (four rating). It almost feels like it is being loved to death in some spots. Nonetheless, if you can get to key destinations early or go off the beaten path, you will be rewarded.

My wife and I spent three days touring the park. The second day was rain and fog, providing an enchanted take on the natural beauty. The last day was bright and sunny. Repeating the circuit trip of day two provided a totally different perspective with equal beauty. I must say that the sun brought out all those too timid to tolerate the rain, so the sunny day was a bit crowded.

Friends and family who recommended this to us were not exaggerating. Acadia National Park has some of the best views in the North East. The only sandy beach we know of Down- East. The drive/hike along the peninsula has several amazing outlooks, all different. (Several are handicap accessible). Bring binoculars and watch the haws, perhaps a bold eagle or the waves. You can drive to the top of Cadillac Mountain where there is a gift shop and restrooms. Get an early start for parking.

Acadia is the most amazingly beautiful national park! It has it all from ocean beaches, mountains to climb, lakes to enjoy, trails to explore. It offers many options so that regardless of your physical abilities, there are places and trails to explore and enjoy. I really loved I could climb my first mountain. We meet some great people along the way from all over the US and other parts of the world. The park staff are incredibly helpful and knowledgeable. Great vacation and plan to be back again, and again and again!
review_title: Has it all-oceans, mountains, lakes, trails!

review_body: First time experience and it is pristine. We especially loved seeing the sunrise on Cadillac Mtn and the trail around the pond. We would hike in the early morning hours and you would hardly pass another soul. So quiet you could listen to the water lapping. Great trip for all ages.

Acadia is absolutely beautiful! We hiked numerous trails in the park, went to scenic outlook spots, and enjoyed watching the waves crash against the shoreline. I am so glad my husband and I came here we made numerous memories that will never be forgotten.
review_title: Put this on your bucket list

review_body: Highly reccomend the drive up Cadillac Mountain and the ferry to Schoodic Point. Wow stuff .... Beautiful waves crashing against the granite boulders.

The park has stunning views of the ocean, cliffs and awesome hiking trails. If we lived in the area we would frequent this park. Only wish it wouldn’t have rained for an entire day that we planned on being in the area. The hiking trails have stunning views, we also choose a horse carriage ride. ( had wanted to rent bikes to ride on the carriage roads but do to surgery we had to change plans) this was a great option to see the carriage roads and learn about the history of the park.

If you are planning a trip to Maine, don't miss out on the beautiful national park! The shoreline views were stunning! Trails are well kept and gorgeous. You can bike or drive all over it too but be warned if you bike, it's very hilly. Parking can be a challenge and we visited on a very busy week but with a bit of patience, we were able to park everywhere we wanted as cars are always coming and going. You can also take the free bus from Bar Harbor and hop on or off. We are Floridians (aka flatlanders) in our 60's but we enjoyed the shoreline hike and the Jordan Pond hike, both relatively flat and just beautiful! Plan ahead and make reservations at the Pond House after your hike! We challenged ourselves with the Great Head Trail, a lot of which is uphill over boulders. It was hard for us but SO worth it! Do it if you're able. There are tons of others of varying intensity and at least drive up Cadillac Mountain for the views. Hats off to the bicyclists pedaling up the mountain!!

Our family of four (boys ages 12 and 14) spent two days exploring the park; wish we had allotted at least one more day to be able to see a bit more. The first night we arrived, we did the two mile loop hike from Bubbles parking lot (we were able to get a parking space at 5:45 pm) using Split Bubble trail to Jordan Pond Shore Trail to South Bubble Trail, including the spur to see Bubble rock - this took us a little under two hours with lots of picture stops and time to skip rocks in Jordan Pond. Saw a beaver dam and the swimming beaver in Jordan Pond. The next day we drove to the summit of Cadillac Mountain for sunrise (it gets crowded, so suggest arriving at least 45 minutes before official sunrise time to get closer parking and to find a good spot to watch). Hang out for a bit after sunrise to enjoy the view and let some of the traffic get off the mountain. Then, we did the 1 mile Bar Island trail out and back and spent some time skipping rocks and exploring the tide pools at low tide from downtown Bar Harbor (check the tide tables, as you can only go to Bar Island for the three hours centered around a low tide). The last day, we got to Sand Beach parking at 8:30 am (the lot was full around 8:45 am) and did approximately a five mile loop starting on Bowl Trail to Gorham Mountain Trial to Shore Trail (out to Otter Cliffs then back to Sand Beach). This took about 3:15 hours, with several stops for drinking water, taking pictures, scrambling on the rocks, watching Thunder Hole, watching rappelling, and admiring the views of Sand Beach, Otter Cliffs and the surrounding areas from the top of the mountain. When we arrived back at Sand Beach at Noon, parking stretched along the road for a long way. We changed into bathing suits and enjoyed the beach and had snacks. The water is beautiful but cold, probably 60 degrees. There is not much shade near the beach. The beach does have changing rooms, bathrooms, water fountain, water bottle filling station, and foot rinsing. We then continued along Park Loop Road to Jordan Pond house, but after several passes were unable to get a parking space, so decided to head off the loop along Route 3 to see the gatehouse, then parked in the Upper Hadlock Pond parking lot and did about a 2 mile hike along two carriage roads (intersections 12 and 13) connected by a hiking path, seeing 3 bridges and a small waterfall. There were carriage road maps at the information kiosk at the parking lot. Be aware that there is no cell signal at Jordan Pond House - we got separated while our driver looked for parking, so had no way to communicate when to reconnect. But, we did have signal in most of the other areas of the park. We used the REI app on our hikes, and we had purchased a hiking book that we used to decide which hikes to do. We also visited Hulls Cove Visitor Center to get our passport stamps, visit the gift shop, and get information - very helpful staff there. We had pre-purchased our 7 day park pass ($30 for a vehicle) online before our arrival, which proved useful since we arrived at ANP after the Thompson Island Information Center had closed (5:00 pm). Note that if you are going through Freeport on your way to Arcadia, the LLBean store sells the park passes. We spent three nights in Bar Harbor at the Villager Motel (good location and value compared to other Bar Harbor Hotels) and spent time exploring Bar Harbor - eating at Blaze, Jordan's, Rosalie's, and the Side Street Cafe plus multiple visits to CJs Big Dipper Ice Cream. We enjoyed the July 4th parade and fireworks in Bar Harbor. The only tour we did during our visit was Diver Ed's Dive In Theater from Bar Harbor, which we highly recommend especially if you are traveling with elementary school kids.
review_title: Rugged coastline, beautiful lakes, nice hiking, gorgeous sunrise

review_body: The trick to Acadia is to figure out where to park outside the park to get to the trails you want to get to inside the park. We purchased the week pass ahead of time but when we got to the park it was just way too crowded and not enough parking - this was a week after labor day - so hate to see what it is like in the Summer. Then we bought a little guide book that showed where all the trails were, how they were connected and where to park outside the park. There is a tremendous range of hiking from very easy carriage roads for long easy walks (or bike rides) to very steep climbing paths. The scenery of course is beautiful - and Cadillac Mountain view does not disappoint. Would to have liked to see some Eagles or more animals/birds in general. Turns out you need to take a nature cruise to some of the islands to see that.

This may have been the most beautiful places I have ever seen. We climbed the Beehive trail, Acadia trail, Jordans pond, and Beach mountain trail. On beach mnt trail I slipped on a wet rock and broke my arm.....in no way can I use this as a strike against my experience here, this is a giant slab of granite and things like this happen.
review_title: Very Good Experience. Except for one small detail

review_body: We have wanted to come here for so long. The coast of Maine in rocky and wild unlike where we live in Southern California. The park is so well laid out and the free bus transportation is just awesome. You can go anywhere you want and don’t need to drive unless it’s in the evening. This seems like a good time of year to visit; less crowds and mild weather. A must see.
AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME! Didn't have enough time so we will be back! We only had time for one trail. A must is getting up early and seeing sun rise on top of Cadillac Mt.

It is easy to see the care and decades of planning that went into making this magnificent park so enjoyable. All of the roads, such as the Loop, drive up to Cadillac Mountain Summit are extremely well paved and smooth. Trails are well marked, Ocean Paths were made to hear and see the coves, sea, and even provide shade on a sunny day. We were thoroughly impressed.
review_title: So much to see and be impressed by natural beauty

review_body: loved everything about this park.....Pond Lake House restaurant had great menu, popovers were amazing......we were lucky had a clear day and top of Cadillac Mtn was amazing....
Beautiful, awe-inspiring, one of the country's great treasures. Whether you just stop at 3 or 4 overlooks, or walk some of the many trails, do not miss!

The park is full of interesting scenery, full of lakes, mountains, and sea views. The trails range from difficult to relaxing, so check a guide book. Parking in certain popular areas can be difficult, so an early start is a good idea.
Thanks to the unselfish generosity of past generations we have this magnificent park to enjoy today! Spectacular view terrain varying from steep and mountainous to beach fronts.
review_title: One of Mother Natures most beautiful places

review_body: We had a nice tour by car around the park whicj costed $30and is around 30miles. A lot of good spot for nice views were you can stop the car and takes photos. We also drove up to Vadillac mountain which is the really nice view. We did not have a real camera unfortunately as views like this is impossible to catch with a mobile. A nice trip aand it took us some hours, I would assume it could be very crowded in high season.
We did a tour of Acadia National Park and learned allot about the park and the island. I would suggest a tour..
Acadia National Park is a really beautiful part of the USA. Must see if you are travelling the north east coast.

We spent 2 days hiking at Arcadia National Park. It was gorgeous! My husband climbed Bee Hive trail which was too strenuous for me, but his photos from the top of the bluff/hill/mountain were breath-taking. I enjoyed sitting on Otter Cliffs, dozing in the sun, and walking through the pebbly sand at the beach located at the end of the Sand Beach trail. We had wonderfully, sunny days while visiting. Cadillac mountain offers more, glorious views! Even if you can't or don't want to hike, the Park Loop Road offers great pull-offs for photo opportunities. Traffic gets heavy, so you will need to have patience when driving along the 2-way stretches of road. When on the 1-way roads, you have passing room if someone is gazing from their car.
The hiking is stunning and not too challenging; the views are breathtaking; and the carriage roads for biking are fabulous. Enjoy every part of this park, it is amazing.
review_title: This park is a gem among gems!

review_body: Acadia National Park is second to none. The trails are in amazing shape. People are very informative. Area is dog and bike friendly. So much to do it's hard to list in one review. If you want to avoid lots of people and cruise ships I would stay on the quiet side of the island, Southwest Harbor. Hiking, biking, site seeing, boat tours, whale watching, great road side stops to eat. Weather is outstanding. I have nothing negative to say about this area. I would do your homework before you leave. It's best to group outings in the areas you are in. This book Discover Acadia National Park, 3rd: AMCs Guide to the best hiking biking and Paddling ISBN 978-1934028292. This book was priceless to have and it includes a map that goes along with book. Some points even give you GPS coordinates to boat launches and trail heads. Enjoy.......Also if you end up staying in Southwest Harbor do yourself a favor and take a trip down Wonderland trail early in the AM. Head to Seawall as well and don't forget Ships Harbor. If you love rocks you will love these areas. Sunset on Cape Rd is second to none. Blows away Cadillac Mt sunset if you would prefer reflections on Ocean.

Wow! What an amazing area! We drove our motorcycles up Cadillac Mountain for sunrise, but we had cooler weather and it was really foggy, but we were both glad we went up! We then drove around the park loop and stopped several places to take it all in. I wish we went for a few hikes, so if you are able to - go for a hike! Everything is so beautiful!
If you are in this part of Maine you must see this park. The views are breathtaking. The trail system is extensive and goes from beginner level to expert.

Spent a day riding around the park! Breath taking is an understatement. It's the kind of place you spend a week and camp and hike and hang. We only had a short weekend to see as much as we could. We were slightly disappointed because they closed 1/2 the Cadillac Mtn parking lot because of an astronomy viewing party. Although it seemed very cool, we just wanted to take in the sights around sunset and not hangout for the whole evening. We did know it was going on but we decided to try anyways. The Thunder Hole was also pretty neat.Too much to mention....but believe all the awesome reviews and get your butt to see Acadia of you haven't. There's plenty for everyone and tons of places to eat and get ice cream in surrounded areas

You need a couple of days to drive around a do the walking trials. Unfortunately there is a lot of road work at the moment with a lot of detours that make it easy to get lost even if you have GPS. The road work was not very well planed and because a 500 metres road closure outside bar harbour you have to do a detour 0f almost 10 miles, if you are lucky and do not get lost. That is not very eco-friendly because of the extra petrol you are using and the carbon footprint. The ticket for the park cost 30 dollars and is valid for a week. There is not an option for a day or two ticket and the tickets allows you to do the brown circuit of the sandy beach and Mount Desert Island. For the rest of the park you do not need a ticket. all in all is expensive in comparison with the White Mountain National Park whose ticket only cost 5 dollars and is equally beautiful.
review_title: Is very nice but be prepared to drive because is huge

review_body: We just scratched the surface but Acadia National Park is a national treasure that is worth a visit. Don’t miss the opportunity to see the earliest sunrise over the continental US.

During a week in September, Acadia National Park & Bar Harbor, Maine host a Night Sky Festival. It's truly a wonderful event for any wannabe astronomers out there. There's lectures at local venues by astronauts, astronomers & professors to inform on our universe. Take a trip out by catamaran to view the night sky while learning the location planets & constellations by a narrator. There's a well orchestrated trip up to Cadillac Mountain where, thanks to Maine's commitment to reducing light pollution, one can see our vast Milky Way splayed out across the night sky. They set up approximately 50-70 telescopes focused on planets, star clusters, the Andromeda galaxy & other spectacular astronomical landmarks. I highly recommend this outing to anyone who wants to learn more about space!

If half-points were allowed I'd give this 4.5, as I prefer the desert parks more. Yet this is a fabulous, beautiful place and easy to navigate. Parking's a bit tight in spots, but otherwise we never felt overcrowded. Can't beat the price (about $20 for a 1-week pass). Trails are clearly marked, and run the gamut from Beehive Trail (very steep, technical climbing, some ladders along cliff-sides -- not for the faint of heights) to Bubble Rock (the north one's better for views) to Ocean Path (easy). Unfortunately, conditions were still and made Thunder Hole a relative flop, but I imagine it's a lot cooler to see with some turbulent weather conditions/winds. Views from Cadillac Mountain are pretty, and easy to get to by car. In all, I'd say 2 full days is enough to experience most of the trails. Park's not overwhelmingly big. If you don't hike at all, 1 day is probably enough to drive the car loop and see the key attractions.
review_title: Beautiful scenery, hiking for all skill levels

review_body: We went on Labor Day weekend, the most popular weekend of the season. There were crowds of tourists, but it was still easy to find private vistas and scenic trails. There is an admission charge for the park, but it's good for a week and well worth the money. Even small, unmarked trails were cleared and well kept. Absolutely stunning!

The mountain and the views are a must see for anyone visiting Bar Harbor. It is absolutely breathtaking. Make sure you take a good camera (not just a phone) to get those pictures that look like a postcard. There is so much history from how the granite and saltwater mixed to the information about the fires in Bar Harbor. I would love to go back and visit again!

Oh my word. This was a beautiful place that I wish we had had more time to explore. We had booked our rooms in advance, three nights near the park and two in Portland. I wish we would have booked all five nights near the park. It was gorgeous. We visited Cadillac Mountain twice, once at sunset and once after sunset. The views are spectacular if not a little scary! You can walk all over and up and down the mountain if you wanted to. There is a handicap accessible trail as well which I loved so that everyone could get the full experience of the park. You can drive straight to the top which makes it a lot easier for us inexperienced hikers. We drove the Park Loop Road and stopped a few times at Jordan's Pond, Eagle Lake, and a few other places. We also walked one of the paths along the ocean near Bar Harbor for a wonderful relaxing time under the shade, watching the waves and the boats. Next time we will know to stay longer and fully explore the park, it was magnificent.
review_title: You need at least a week here, possibly more!

review_body: Love Cadillac Mtn. It always mesmerized me. The beach is beautifu. Thunder Hole is beautiful whether it's thundering or calm.
review_title: Cadillac Mtn, the best place to view the area

review_body: Easily accessible . Beautiful place. You say hi to a stranger and they reply “this is such a beautiful place”. They are correct. 5 hrs from Boston area. Go there. You will be glad you did
review_title: Not a more breath taking place around

review_body: Super easy to navigate and to get in and out of most places fairly painlessly. Recommend Cadillac Mountain or Beehive, Jordan Pond (Bubble Rock), Boulder Beach and Otter CliffsSieur de Monts (Jesup Path), all of which can be seen via the 27 mile loop (The Coastal Trail)

Not sure what more I can add to the reviews below. This place has everything. Once you enter and check out your first scenic view of the ocean, mountain, beach, tree, hike, eye...you are memorized and hooked in. Everyone needs to go here. This place is the reason the NPS are amaxing .... No place like it, at least in America. High praise. Awesome
review_title: If I can give a higher rating, I would

review_body: This park is like no other National Park I’ve visited. Seems to be open 24/7. Only one time we’re we stopped at a gate to show the park pass. Great for hiking, biking,scenic views and even horse drawn carriage. Can have your own horse if you bring it with you. Did the Jordan pond hike, coastal hike with the thunder hole, Cadillac Mountain is a must! Incredible views and just a unique park.

We started our hike at Otter Point and walked the ocean path toward sand beach. Then went up the Beehive Trail. That trail was both mentally and physically demanding but the view from the top was worth it. Then we made our way back down the back of Beehive toward The Bowl and back to the Ocean Path. It was about a 5 mile trek. We then drove up to the Cadillac Mountain summit to take in the views. Gorgeous!!!

The park is amazing. There are hikes and trails for every skill level, from easy carriage trail paths to more advanced trails up some of the peaks. If you're unable to hike, you can also see some great views just driving the park loop road and up Cadillac Mountain. Can't wait to visit again.

He hit Cadillac Mt, Jordan Pond and Sand Beach for a quick half day trip. I would stay in the area and spend time here longer. If you buy the car permit online, you still have to get the physical tag for the car so you don't get ticketed. We got ours at the visitor center. If you have time to use the bus service, do it. Parking can be a pain in the peak season/warmer months. The views and attractions are great. Again, depending on the year will determine how crowded the park is but going here is not a disappointment, believe the hype.

If you’re not into long hikes this is the perfect place for one full day drive around the loop and up Cadillac mountain. We started with the short 15 min movie at the visitors center. Then drove up Cadillac mountain- don’t worry about stopping at any pull outs on the way up, just concentrate on finding the coveted spots at the top. Follow the path at the top around and enjoy the walk.Then do the loop. Most of the stops are within the first 7-8 Miles near sand beach. Definitely be sure to stop when you can as it’s a one way loop.You can buy a park pass at the visitor center. Don’t try to cheat the park.
review_title: Short Visit but That’s All You Need

review_body: A group of friends and I were able to climb at Otter Cliffs over Labor Day weekend. Highly recommend as the opportunity to climb with an ocean front backdrop is few and far between.
This was my first visit to Maine, and I can't wait to go back. Every single hike we breathtaking - can't wait to return.
This place is everything that everyone said it would be. The scenery is beautiful and the views are spectacular.

Living in New England, we normally spend 2 weeks a year in Acadia National Park. We mostly hike the peaks in Acadia, most which are more accessible then the bigger mountains elsewhere.There are also nice drives around the island, and some cute beaches one can chill at (I wouldn't suggest going in the ocean there, it is cold).Only problem I have is none of the buses go up to Cadillac Mountain, despite them having a large parking lot, so if you are having problems hiking up to the peak, there is no easy way down.

Acadia national park is a must see. The water views alone are worth the visit. Cadillac mountain is a result of volcanic activity and the granite formations are awesome to behold. There is plenty of hiking trails, lakes to kayak on, and just incrediable ocean views.
review_title: beautiful park with breath taking scenery

review_body: Highly recommend Cadillac Mountain, Sandy Beach, and Jordan Pond. If you can avoid holiday weekend...parking was non existent.

I have visited most of the major national parks in the US. Each is unique and this one is no exception. I would describe this one as a little similar to Yosemite but on the Ocean. Lots of woodlands, granite boulders, moderate mountains to hike and beautiful coastal views all over. You can drive the main loop of the park (the Park Loop road) on a mainly one way road in about an hour if you don't stop. Even from the road the views are beautiful but there is plenty of hiking available as well as an extensive network of carriage roads for biking.
review_title: Breathtaking views even from the road

review_body: When you purchase a park pass in town it includes free shuttles to this beautiful park. We chose to do the Ocean Trail hike/walk. Happy we took the shuttle driver’s advice and started at Otter Point and ended at Sand Beach which is busier and has facilities. It is an easy walk with amazing scenery. There are numerous places to go off trail and explore the rocky coastline. Nice option for a picnic but of course be safe.

We drove over 1000 miles with trailer/kayak in tow, with the intention of kayaking/fishing in the park. The pros: Only one. It is absolutely beautiful. The cons: There is only 1 Visitor Center, which you have to climb to get to. The gift shop area is the smallest I've ever seen. It's 90% books, no shot glasses(which I collect) & 1 choice of t-shirt. No hat/t-shirt combo like at all the other NP'S. They could generate so much revenue if they'd expand this area & offer more choices. So now we're driving on the Loop & come to the Sand Beach Entrance Station. 3 booths are open. We had already tackled the climb to get our pass, but had to sit in line behind people purchasing theirs & asking questions. Would it kill them to make one of those lines an Express, for those who already have their pass??? There is absolutely no other Ranger presence in the park, except at entrances. On the entire 27 miles of Loop Road, there are only TWO picnic areas. Parking is a NIGHTMARE! They do warn you & advise you to use their bus system. If we didn't have plans of kayaking, we would of utilized the shuttle buses. We had put the kayak on our car & left the trailer at the campground, just for that reason. Our first attempt was at the boat launch at Jordan Pond. We drove through the parking lot twice. It was very clear that most of the "launch" parking spots were filled with non boaters/kayakers. So we continued on. We found the same situation at Eagle Lake, even though it states NO SWIMMING, that is who was bogarting all the parking spots. We finally were able to find a parking spot at the launch at Echo Lake, but had to park & carry to the water. Dodging all the swimmers was a nightmare. even though the brochure states it was "closed to swimming and wading", there was no one there to enforce this. We gave up even trying at the others. We're glad we went. Got some beautiful pictures of the coast & crossed Acadia off our National Park list, BUT we will never go back.
review_title: Views were a amazing...park it self, very disappointing

review_body: I highly recommend visiting this National Gem. Cadillac Mountain is a must see. The views are beyond what words can describe. I would recommend going on a non holiday weekend. The Sandy Beach area was very unique. Being from NC, we know what beaches are but never had the opportunity to see one in a cove with rocks on both sides.

Wish I had come to Acadia when my kids were younger. But now I will bring my adult children and grandchildren here whenever and as many times as I can. Hiking - just walking the trails is an experience that should not be missed. One "tram tour" is a good idea for info and history, but the best is seen on foot. Summer can get somewhat crowded but doesn't ruin it. However, if you can do it, Sept or early October is really ideal time to visit (but avoiding Columbus day weekend).
review_title: Amazing Place - Hiking trails for ALL levels

review_body: My husband and I just came to Mt Desert Island for a week to celebrate our anniversary. As we are trying to go to all the National Parks, Acadia was our main point of interest in the area and boy did it not disappoint. The hiking was the best I’ve ever done going through multiple eco systems with gorgeous views and well kept trails. For the adventurous I recommend the beehive and precipice trail. For a less scary buy still strenuous hike I recommend the Gormund trail to the bowl and die through the Cadillac cliffs. And for an easy or family friendly stroll I recommend Jordan Pond, Bar Island, and Wonderland Trail. There is literally something for everyone here. Don’t miss watching the sun rise over Cadillac Mountain or star gazing from Ocean Drive. The summer months are busy so I recommend getting to the trails early for easy parking as well uncongested trails. We got there around 6:30 AM and basically had the trails to ourselves.
Great View and well preserved. Plenty to see from the top, biking and hiking trails available. Has a great history.
Alot of other cars but just pull over and enjoy. Peaceful..Take plenty of water and snacks. Go hiking because its beautiful. Then go for Lobster out at a picnic table restraunt. Perfect day.
Great free bus system. All levels of hiking. Easy walk around Jordan Lake. More challenging hiking up Dorr mountain. Something for all ages.
The place is stunning...Hiking for all levels of outdoor person. Views that will take your breath away. Accessibility for people to see some of the highlights in the park was impressive.
review_title: Best Nationl Park I have been to.... I loved it!

review_body: We are not avid hikers like a lot of visitors here, but we still enjoyed the park immensley. There was so much to do that we were busy every day exploring the many scenic spots. The Granite Museum is in an old building but the inside had dioramas, tools, and photos of the early granite quarry operations. The guide was very knowledgeable and interesting. Of course Cadillac Mountain, Bubble Mountain rock, Thunder Hole, Jordan Pond, Sand Beach, and Otter Cliffs were all beautiful. I think the Jordan Pond Restaurant is a little overrated. Their service was poor and had an overpriced menu. You can get the same famous "popover" roll in a nearby Southwest Harbor restaurant at half the price. We also enjoyed eating at the unique Pickled Wrinkle restaurant in Birch Harbor. The Rockefeller Carriage Ride is also worth your time!
Acadia is beautiful with plenty to see and do. Many hikes for all levels, endless viewpoints and abundance of fauna and flora.

Amazing park. Great scenery. Loved our trip to Acadia.We did 1 day in Acadia and another day going around places like Echo Lake, Bass Harbor/Head Light, Southwest Harbor, Seawall, etc.Overall, our trip was memorable.
Make sure to walk around Jordan pond and eat at the restaurant there. Arrive early to avoid parking waits.
This park is huge. Prepare to walk till you can't walk anymore. Only made it to the Bubble and the pond in one day's hike. So much more to see.

This place is the kind of place you could come back to every year and always find a new corner of heaven. We packed our trip to the gills with hiking, kayaking, amazing restaurants, sites, and attractions and barely touched the surface. Each day was a delight. Even visiting some of the same sites multiple times brought a new adventure as the sun, fog, clouds, and people made it exciting and new. The maps are well thought out and the trails are well maintained. You can see the love that goes into maintaining this National Park.
Visited during a guided tour of Bar Harbor. Would love to go back and hike, bike or horseback ride on the carriage trails.

Acadia National Park is spectacular--we drove the Loop Road after going to the top of Cadillac Mountain. The park is easy to navigate and is the greenest place I have ever seen. Only problem is there are few places to get a bite, so bring your lunch!

Took the day to tour Acadia National Park. The visitors center rangers were very helpful and mapped out a route for me - driving and hiking. It was a fantastic day to hit the park. The hikes recommended were easy enough to handle but strenuous enough to be a good workout. Cadillac Mountain is a great point to get out and see the surrounding area - and truly see that the park sits on Mount Desert Island.

We spent 2 1/2 days in Bar Harbor/Acadia and the park is the absolute highlight of the trip. The park loop road was great, so much to see, and plenty of places to pull over, get out, take photos and video, and just enjoy the scenery. My favorite was the drive up Cadillac Mountain, and the visual treats you will enjoy once up there. We also got to walk on Sand Beach, and we found a perfect mussel shell that we will make an ornament out of. Thunder hole wasn't "thundering" when we got there, but still pretty neat. The Jordan Pond thing seems a bit over-crowded & over-rated, hundreds & hundreds of people wanting to eat scones? No thanks. Get out and explore, we covered pretty much the whole island, all the way down to Bass Harbor. The town of Bar Harbor itself was a disappointment. NO WHERE to park. Forget it. Take the free island shuttle, get dropped off, do the town, then take the shuttle back to your motel. If I ever come back here again, and can afford it, I would just bite the bullet, and pay for a room in town.
review_title: Very nice, simply beatiful scenery. Park Loop Rd. is fantastic.

review_body: Spent a few days at Acadia and the views are gorgeous, hiking for all different levels is available and did some of the most scenic road cycling including a climb up Cadillac Mountain. Wear appropriate footwear, clothing and bring water and snacks. We did the challengng Beehive trail, intermediate Jordan Pond loop and cycled up Cadillac Mountain 3-40 minutes of climbing. Pick your times with Sand Beach filling up by 9am, Cadillac Mountain is best between sunrise lookers and 9am. Park Loop was great at 8:30-9am. Nature at it's best.
review_title: Nature at it's best - a bit overcrowded at times/locations

review_body: Visited this beloved national park in Summer... over several days, we visited all 3 sections: the main Mt Desert Island parts, Schoodic point, and Isle Au Haut. The highlights are, of course, on Mt Desert Island. Park at the visitors center, and there's great, free shuttle bus service to all the main spots. Highlight was Jordan Pond, but we loved hiking around all day.Even our stop in Bar Harbor was a fun. A tourist trap-y kind of town, but well worth the visit anyway. If you can't find accommodations nearby, Bangor is an easy drive away.
review_title: Beautiful national park. Shows why Maine is one of US's most gorgeous states.

review_body: ...it was a bit of a yawn.Pretty scenery, but we didn't see any wildlife. Just not understanding the hoopla surrounding it.
review_title: Yawn. It was nice, but honestly after seeing so many National Parks...

review_body: I have wanted to go to Acadia for a long time and this trip did not disappoint. We enjoyed everything about our trip. We got the park pass for 1 week and used it every day of our trip. We did park loop road multiple times and took the time to stop and do some exploring. The views on this trip were amazing and we could not stop taking pictures! We will definitely be back!
Every turn of the road was just spectacular. the wildlife was amazing. weather was perfect. get out and enjoy this place
Loop drive very nice with mostly ample parking. Some pretty sea views along the rocky coast. Many hiking and carriage trails. Cadillac mountain had great views of Bar Harbor and off shore islands. 6
review_title: Best and only National Park on East coast of USA

review_body: Every part of Acadia was amazing. We spent several days kicking the trails, riding bikes on the carriage roads, and exploring the park on foot. Make sure you have comfortable clothes, shoes and sunscreen plus lots of room on your camera.

We visited Arcadia National Park in August and spent 3 nights at the Coach Stop B&B nearby (a good location). The park is easy to get to and the loop drive takes you around the entire park in a good orientation (with lots of places to pull over). I recommend going to the visitor's center for advice on the best way to see it. So here are some hints to enjoy the park. We wanted to walk the coastal trail along the rocks etc. and parked in the Otter point parking lot and walked the 2.5 miles along the incredibly beautiful trail to the Sandy Beach. where we got a bus to take us back. Lunch was at the Jordon Pond house (with their famous popovers) and then we walked on some of the magnificent carriage roads through woods that were created by Rockefeller and donated to the park. Cadillac mountain is also a must for the view. In all honesty, one of my favorite places was not in the main part of the park, but on the "quiet side" of the island near Bass Harbor. Not only is there a very picturesque lighthouse there, but there are two walks (we took the Ship Harbor trail) to take from the parking area, through woods that come out to the ocean and wonderful rocks. The views are just lovely, the rocks are a little flatter than in the main park and there are tidal pools (at low tide) that have all kinds of things to see. A good place for a picnic too. (Carry in/out). When we were there, there were lots of kids enjoying them. That "side" of the island is less "commercial" with small New England towns and lots of places to eat. Would highly recommend going there, it was just wonderful.
review_title: Visit more than just the main sites

review_body: We were there in the middle of August. I think September would have been better when vacations were over. On our first full day (a Saturday) the weather was cloudy with on and off rain. This definitely kept the crowds down and we didn't have any problems navigating the park. However, from the top of Cadillac Mountain, the view was misty. We climbed up to South Bubble Rock -- about a 1/2f mile hike. It was moderately strenuous. We also went to Jordan's Pond which was lovely and we had lunch at the restaurant overlooking the water (see separate review). We went to the Wild Gardens of Acadia. I thought we would see flowers, but it was mainly green plants. We didn't spend much time there.The next day it was sunny. We got up early and went to the top of Cadillac Mountain again and the view was much better although still a little misty. We got there at 8:30am and there was plenty of parking. By 10:00 the park was filling up. We went back to Jordan's Pond for lunch but couldn't find a parking space in either lot. On the cloudy day before there were plenty of them. So, we then went to Sand Beach -- crowded but we found a space. We walked around on the huge rocks and took in the scenery. It was fun.Even though Acadia can't compare with the awesome and magnificent parks out west, it was still a worthwhile visit. But don't go in July or August. In fact, my friend was there in the middle to late June, and she said it was crowded then too. 0

The unparalleled beauty of this forested, mountain in the Atlantic Ocean has rejuvenated my spirit. Nature will do this to you. The colorful and quiet sunset on Cadillac Mt..The awe inspiring ocean vistas from the mountains. The hikes along the rocky coast and through pine forest. The several whale sightings from the whale watch cruise. It is so easy to enjoy nature here! It will rejuvenate your spirit!
review_title: One of the Best National Parks in USA

review_body: Wonderful national park with something for everyone, including a sandy beach accessible by car. Wonderful vistas, great hiking or just hanging out.

Really great park to see the beauty of the Maine coastline. We only had a couple days and one day it rained pretty hard so we only drove through the park and stopped at Cadillac Mountain and we checked out the stables. The views from the Mountain which is the highest point on the US East Coast was fantastic, and should not be missed. There were a lot of people in the park, but on our day we were able to drive easily to the top of Cadillac Mountain and found parking to take some pictures. The stables were very well maintained and if I had more time I would have liked to enjoy a ride in a wagon.
review_title: Great National Park and worth a visit

review_body: Acadia has been our favorite NP for many years. It has fantastic ocean views, hiking for all abilities, graveled carriage road to bike ride or if you are gonzo do the Park Loop Rd 27 mi. or for a finally Bike to the top to Cadillac Mt on a paved road.There are ton's of and a huge variety of accommodations. Dining to soot any palate.
review_title: Acadia is a true gem of a National Park

review_body: So much to see and do, you won't be able to fit it all in. Do some hikes and check out the carriage roads. Pick hikes that match your skill level, there are so many to choose from and all offer something unique. Walk or bike a carriage road! There are excellent maps available. The stone bridges are awesome! We even had a foggy day and that actually made it really beautiful. A pass is only $30.00 for your car and it's good for a week. Rangers are very helpful. If you have children, check out the Junior Ranger program - lots of activities to take part in.
review_title: This was one of the reasons we came!

review_body: Lots of fun, weather was great - no humidity! Hiked several trails and loads of outdoor activities to do!

One of my favorite places on the planet. Have been coming here since the late 1970s, and thankfully, its natural beauty endures. Lovely walking trails; lovely more challenging trails for a hike. There is nothing better than sitting on the rocks with your family beside Thunder Hole on a sunny day. Well, maybe the view from the top of Cadillac Mountain on a sunny day. Much appreciate the devoted volunteers who offer nature talks. Have a civilized break at the Jordan Pond House (go on off hours, peak meal times, the wait is long). Bar Harbor close by. Breathe in the clear air and rejoice that parks like this are preserved.
review_title: Stunning, timeless, may it never change.

review_body: This is a must do if you are in the area. You can bike, hike, walk or drive, depending on your ability. The views are gorgeous! You could take hundreds of pictures and still not capture it's beauty.

I have been to Acadia National Park many times and each time I love it just as much. There is so much to see and do from Cadillac Mountain and then the drive through the park along the coast line. Highly recommend it for the sheer beauty of the area!
This park is in an idyllic setting. Great scenic overviews of bays and ocean. Excellent hiking throughout. Great sunsets. Must visit national park on the east coast!

Allow yourself as much time as possible to enjoy the countless breath-taking views, cliffs, rock faces and formations, forests, wildflowers, ferns/mosses/lichen, red squirrels, climbing/hiking trails, beaches, gardens and gift shops that can be accessed in this treasure called Acadia National Park.
review_title: More Breathtaking than I could have imagined

review_body: Hiked from Jordan Pond up to Cadillac and then down to bubble pond. It was a challenging hike, but the trail was well marked “stay in the blue”.

We bought the $30 Vehicle pass (good for 5 days). In order to see it all, it may take that long. We drove to the top of Cadillac Mountain (the view is awesome), then to Jordan Pond which has an easy to navigate hiking trail that circles the entire pond. We then visited Sand Beach (parking is tough in the closest lot) and walked the Ocean Trail (just beautiful) and stopped at Thunder Hole.
Wonderful place to vacation with young children. Hikes of all leves and beautiful scenery. Great food nearby and plenty to do.

Acadia is one of the most beautiful regions that I have ever seen. An exciting opportunity for you, as a visitor, is to see the earliest sunrise in North America from on top of Cadillac Mountain. Due to its elevation and proximity to the coast the sunrise is visible here before it is seen anywhere else in North America.A Must See during your vacation adventure in Maine

We spent several hours driving along the routes in this national park. Our park pass from Fort Pickens in Pensacola Beach gave us easy & free access. The day was a bit cloudy so we were not able to enjoy the sunset over Cadillac Mountain as we had hoped to do.

Loved, loved , loved this. Brought our young adult children who could've stayed for days. The buses are so easy to use and clean. Acadia is just beautiful, even though it was foggy for the first few hours. Trails are labeled well. Just wish maps were provided. and wish we had more days. We hiked the coastal easy trail and then a moderate trail (that seemed more that moderate!) but was so worth the work!

A lot to see and do here for outdoor enthusiasts. First, you get a 1 week park pass costing $30 per car at one of the ranger stations or several other locations that sell them. In addition to hiking the many miles of trails in Acadia, we hiked and rode bikes on the miles of carriage roads in the park. There is too much excellent scenery to list here, but the best views are offered from on top of Cadillac Mountain as well as the coastal trail from Sand Beach to Otter Point passing Thunder Hole. Hiking around Jordan Pond is an excellent hike with great pond views and I recommend eating a popover at the Jordan Pond House, which we did. I recommend going early in order to find parking spaces as they fill up quickly later in the morning. We hiked or biked every day except on a rainy day when we visited the Dorr and Abbe Museums as well as the Bar Harbor Historical Society Museum - all in Bar Harbor. They are small, but good museums. There is no swimming allowed in any of the park's fresh water ponds, but swimming is allowed at Sand Beach, if you can withstand the ocean's cold water temps. Also, we walked out to Bar Island and walked the trail which you can only do during low tides. As a result, there are signs telling visitors of when the low and high tides are coming during the month. Outside of the park, you can take boat rides to Baker Island to see the lighthouse or out to Little Cranberry Island, which we did from Northeast harbor. This tour was excellent, informative and we got to visit the Islesford Museum on the island. Overall, it's a great way to spend a vacation and if you can you should definitely visit this great park.

A beautiful meeting of roughing it with convenience! Enough trails and nature with quaint towns full of art, food,and points of interest for all ages and levels of participation. Staying at Seawall campground gave us the sound of crashing surf to fall asleep to while nestled among the trees. Wonderland trail feels just like that, falling through the looking glass to another world of adventure and intrigue. Cadillac Mountain will not disappointdisappoint- whether hiking or driving! Definitely a must see, must stay, must enjoy National Park!

When visiting New England, don't pass up a chance to go to ANP on Mount Desert Island (MDI). So many varied features that are stunning, amazing, exhilarating, serene, and soporific. This is needs to be on your bucket list.
review_title: A top 10 destination in New England!

review_body: We have grown to love visiting Acadia National Park.Cadillac Mountain is a pleasant locale to view sunset. (Road is closed about 30 minutes before sunset and parking is tight.)The Loop Road is least crowded if you start before 9 A, giving easy parking for most attractions.It is easy to spend hours here, even more if you hike.Very popular in Summer.

So much to do here! My family and I started off with walking the Land Bridge at low tide and then hiked Bar Island. Also, went to beautiful Sand Beach and hiked the Great Head trails. Saw Thunder Hole, drove to the top of Cadillac Mt which has many gorgeous views. My husband and son enjoyed hiking the Beehive and Gorham Mt, but one of my favorites was exploring/hiking Beech Mt. The views of Long Pond and Echo Lake are amazing from Beech Mt. Don't miss Jordan Pond and Bubble Mt. too. LOTS and LOTS of traffic though. Almost impossible to get a parking spot in some areas.

The park is one of our national parks and not to be missed. Gorgeous views, clean and pristine. VERY crowded and slow traffic in several areas but not enough to ruin the experience. Many places to pull off and take great pictures. View from the top of Cadillac Mountain is extrordinary!

We were lucky to be able to visit this park over several days and enjoyed it immensely. In addition to being awed by our surroundings, we were impressed by the many friendly travelers we interacted with. It was great to see families with young children and seniors hiking. While some trails are gravel-based, the island is rocky, and you will have to navigate stones in many areas. Popular trails are well-maintained and some trailheads have bathrooms and fountains to replenish water bottles. The only restaurant is at Jordon Pond and the popovers are legendary. Popover: airy biscuit eaten with butter and jam. Shuttle buses fill up quickly and individuals stand in the aisles as well. Sometimes we were lucky with timing, and during one visit endured an extra hour of travel due to waiting. This park has mountains, lakes, carriage trail rides, and areas to bike-ride and explore. The sky’s the limit!

We spent a week on MDI and explored all over Acadia. I prefer the trail heads that are not on the park loop road, b/c you still get all the beauty but less of the crowd. Many of those trails are more secluded.

We were in Bar Harbour for the day on a cruise ship and visited Acadia national Park as part of an Oli's Trolley Tour. It is a very beautiful place with lots of places to see. Much bigger that we imagined and had some great views over Bar Harbour from the highest point. Well worth the visit and do it with a guide, so you can learn about ll the history.Highly recommend.

Take the official bus tour, about $50-60 for 2 adults, with tickets at Testa's restaurant. Buses are directly across from the restaurant. The driver provider a wonderful explanation of the national park. The tour stops about 3 or 4 times for photos and more history of the stops. We were in Bar Harbor in the summer and it was unusually hot with lots of car traffic. So glad we did not have to drive around looking for a parking space. A truly beautiful park.
This place has something for everyone. Camping. Swimming. Beaches . Hiking. Bouldering. Biking. Rock climbing. Kayaking. Extreme hiking. You To name it. They got it.
review_title: This is always gonna be #1 east coast national Park.

review_body: We took a 2 1/2 bus tour and are glad we did. The narration gave us lots of good information. Be sure to sit on the left side of the bus - better ocean photos that way!!!!
review_title: Another gem of a National Park!

review_body: My family and I traveled to Acadia National Park and Bar Harbor in August 2018 and we had an absolute blast! There is so much to see and do! The Park Loop Road is a great way to see the park. It is a 27-mile loop road that takes you around the best sights in the park such as Cadillac Mountain, Jordan Pond House, Otter Point, Thunder Hole, and Sand Beach. For each major spot to see, that was on the map, there was only a short walk to each place. It was very busy and there was a lot of traffic in the major spots in the park. Make sure to get there early and you will really enjoy your trip to Acadia!
review_title: YOU JUST HAVE TO SEE ACADIA NATIONAL PARK!

review_body: We took a tour around the island and it was breath taking. A must see if you are in the area. So many different areas and it was is as Beautiful as the other. .
This park has some gems,and you need to arive early to beat the crouds lots of thing to see. lots of trails with easy hikes

Sonya and I have wanted to get up here for years but life just kept getting in the way. We love New England in the winter because well its winter and the crowd are way less. This was the case in Acadia. I know this area is packed in the warm weather and we hate that. We were able to spend just a few hours in the park and the natural beauty is truly breathtaking. I bet during the summer the trails are perfectly maintained too. We will be back when there is no snow on the ground.
review_title: Just the best National Park in the East

review_body: Try the Beehive hike...as long as you're moderately in shape and capable of hiking it's fine. The views are totally worth it.

Acadia is absolutely stunning. It is also insanely crowded. The sheer volume of visitors does detract from the experience. The parking is nearly impossible at any of the main attractions in the park. If Acadia is a place you've longed to visit go to their website and thoroughly research and plan your trip in the offpeak season. The park itself as far as beauty and pristine condition is without equal though.

Had a great few days in Acadia! Maine has friendly people, natural beauty, and Acadia offers a unique blend of the mountains and ocean. We actually stayed in Ellsworth (Hampton Inn was a thumbs up) which was also less expensive than the name hotels on the island. But Ellsworth is about 25 mins away from the island. The view from Cadillac mountain is majestic and there are nice running trails (especially the Ocean View trail that starts at Sand Beach and goes aside the Park Loop road to Otters Point) for a morning run. Sand beach is a small beach area where we sat on the rocks and beach but did not enter the water (a little cool for me). However, there were many brave souls swimming and playing in the water. Changing rooms are available if you choose to swim. Sieur de Monts was also a place we visited. Carriage roads around Jordan Pond house are worth checking out but I would not recommend eating at Jordan Pond House except for the popovers. Food was poor and service was even worse. Better eating options on the island are Adelman’s Deli, West Street Café and CJ’s ice cream. Also, Lobster Pound and Real Pit BBQ is a good BBQ place on the side of the road from Bar Harbor and Elllsworth. We were not able to go kayaking as we didn’t plan in advance—so book early. Would also recommend the Atlantic Brewing Company for a 30 min tour plus sampling—this is also a good option when it is raining. On our way back we stopped over for a night in Portsmouth, NH—historical town and good eating options by the river. In sum, we had fun and I would visit Acadia again!

Come to Bar Harbor to relax, unwind, shop, fish, swim, sail or kayak. But the star of the trip is Acadia. There’s something for everyone. Handicap accessible to daring cliff hanging bikes & climbs. Great for the recreational or cycling fanatic. Pay the fee to drive the one way Park Loop Road. Take your time & stop for scenic pictures along the way. Get up early and drive or hike to the top of Cadillac Mountain. Grab a map and list of activities at the visitor center. Plan ahead or take it in stride. This is a bucket list type of place.
This park was spectacular! The views from everywhere are gorgeous. The park is very clean. Nice place to visit.
We went in July and it was super crowded. Was hard to find a quiet peaceful place on the loop. I would definitely visit again but maybe in fall or spring. Too many people ruin the park for me.
The Acadia National Park is as beautiful and as enjoyable as any of our national parks. Make sure to take some time to explore.
