The only national park on the east coast is an absolute must see when visiting Maine. Breathtaking vistas around every turn. Very easy to drive and stop at countless scenic turn-outs or take the ultra-convenient Island Explorer busses and let them do the driving. Great hiking for all ability levels. Biking and romantic carriage rides on the carriage only carriage roads. Construction project on the way in is inconvenient but worth it. Great camping, shopping and dining nearby. Do stop at Jordan Pond House in the park and get the iconic Popovers even if there is a long wait. You'll be impressed. Sit on the lawn if possible and imagine you're dining with the Rockefellers back in the day.
We had a great day cruising around the park and stopping to enjoy the sights and take a few hikes. Make this a destination spot if you enjoy the outdoors and beautiful scenery.
review_title: One of my favorite places on earth

review_body: It is a oddly laid out park that for your first visit will require map reading or using your GPS to find what you want.It's easy to find yourself out of the park and in one of the towns/villages. But in areas you must do this to see the next sections.Lots of great pullouts along the drives with wonderful views. Many great trails. Be sure to read the info re the trails as certain ones won't be for many due to ladders etc. (I will add or have details on few trails.) I was surprised just how clean the restrooms were when I had my picnic etc.Depending where you enter it Will determine where you have to stop and but your park pass. Going in from the Ellsworth entrance you stop into the visitor center. FYI it was a zoo on the Sat. I visited! Lines for everything.I never really had any issues finding a place to park. No was the traffic IN the park bad. There are many options around for good and gas and lodging right in and around the park area.Late Aug. I didn't need bug spray, shorts were fine and only light coat for a.m.'s.

If you are in Bar Harbor and you don't spend time in Acadia, you are missing the best part of your journey. We stayed in Bar Harbor for a week, and we were in Acadia 6 days out of 7. Cadillac Mountain is amazing. Jordon Pond House. Horse drawn carriage ride at Wildwood Stable. Ocean Drive. You need to time your visit. If you are there at a busy time, try to arrive there at 3 or so. That's when the crowds leave. Whatever you need to do, do it -- it's worth it. Thanks to the Rockefeller family for this wonder.

Bsar Harbor was nice, but Acadia is the highlight. Take the extra day to visit the park. There is a shuttle, but you can also take a car, It was surprising to me that in July it was a very under-visited park. Coming from California, it was nice to visit a park and not be elbow deep with other tourists.

I am so grateful to the people who donated land for this spectacular park. I am also grateful to those who worked to preserve it and those who volunteer today to maintain it. One of the best national parks I have visited.
review_title: Such a Beautiful place in our world

review_body: This was a wonderful National Park to visit. The views are outstanding. We are so lucky to have access to this type of resource. Go and just enjoy!

Took the 4hr "Olly's Trolly" tour of the park, was a great deal. We stopped at 4 locations with 30 minute to walk around & enjoy the sites. The park is beautiful. The roads are very congested with cars & tons of bikes, so glad we didn't drive. Many places there was no parking or it was full, and cars park in right lane of 2 lane road. Highly recommend watching the sunset on top of Cadilac Mountain, take a jacket, gets very chilly. If unable to bike the carriage trails, there is a horse drawn carriage that travels them, but need to make reservations early, it books up fast.
This park has everything from hiking to biking to just driving the loop. There is camping and picnicking and a special restaurant. Something for everyone! Well worth the visit!

We drove up from Camden for a day trip to Bar Harbor and Acadia National Park. It was a full 7 hour day, as we made several detours on the way. We drove down the peninsula to the Bass Harbor Head Lighthouse. There wasn't a lot to see on the way, but if seeing lighthouses is on your list of things to see and do, then it is worth the drive. Don't miss the path that takes you out to the rocky coast with a different view of the lighthouse. The entrance to the path is to the left of the lighthouse from the parking lot. It was worth the short hike. Then we drove up to Cadillac Mountain. The views from there were beautiful - great views of Bar Harbor and Eagle Lake. We didn't have time to explore the rest of the park, but it looked like there were many trails to hike that I'm sure also gave great views.I don't regret making the drive from Camden to experience this park.

Acadia National Park is indeed beautiful, but we feel it's somewhat overrated. It's not as amazing or breath-taking as the National parks in the west. It's the best of New England, and worth a visit if you're in the area, but we would not fly here from far away.Bar Harbor is a cute little town, colorful and fun, marinas, souvenir shops, lots of lobster restaurants (irrelevant for us), nice friendly people, pleasant atmosphere. Very touristy, all about shopping and pricey dining.There are free shuttle buses to tiwn and the park, but they run infrequently (especially those that carry bikes). Yet it's sometimes better than driving, since parking is tough. Parking near the Jordan Pond House around lunch in the summer is impossible, took us more than an hour of driving around. All lots were full, and the staff would not allow parking on road sides. Also at the top of Cadillac mountain before sunset, the staff would rather enforce regulations than let people enjoy a rare experience. The restaurant at Jordan Pond House is the only place to buy food, you can wait an hour just to get seated, and prices are high. Try to get there off peak hours, or bring your own food to the park.Biking is fun, there are nice trails around lakes etc. But there's nowhere to drink, so carry lots of water with you.If you don't come with high expectations, you can enjoy and have a good time.

This is our 3rd year in a row visiting this area. Main part of park offers 27 miles of beautiful scenery with breathtaking views rocky coastline lots of hiking trails great for bicycle riding Shuttle system is available for those who do not want to drive all areas.
review_title: Beautiful Arcadia National Park beautiful combination of land and Sea

review_body: We drove up Cadilac Mountain early in the morning, and found out we should have gone earlier for the sunrise. Hundreds of people were hiking all over the mountain. View was a breathtaking 360 degree panorama out over the islands and down to Bar Harbor. We then went to the beach. From there we saw many people rock climbing up the mountain. The beach is very nice and sheltered and from there you can access the Ocean Trail, which is a pleasant walk along the rocky shore, with many paths down to the shore.
review_title: Super way to spend a day

review_body: Our favorite moment on our three week trip in North-East US was the walk we made in this fantastic park. We walked the Pemetic walk, starting from Jordan pond, where we luckily found a place to park. You need a permit to drive in the park. There is only a one week option of 25$, which is a pitty when you're only there for 2 days, as in our case. Fantastic views. On our second and last evening we wanted to enjoy the sunset and arrived a good 20 minutes before it would happen on the foot. We weren't allowed to drive up Cadillac mountain as it was 'full'. The ranger blocking the road could have been more friendly or in any case communicative for us non-US citizens having questions about the road block. Still it didn't spoil our stay here as we saw the sun going down behind the tree line driving out of the park.
review_title: Fantastic walks - plan sunset on Cadillac well in time

review_body: Really were blow away at the beauty of the park. Definitely get your bones out of bed an do the sunrise view on Cadillac Mountain. We left about 4:15AM and drove up, very easy drive. At the time people have already claimed some spots and parking was easy to find. Bring cushions and blankets and coffee. Otherwise do trail hikes and carriage rides, etc.

An absolute must-visit, especially if you live around the Northeast. It's a 5-6 hour drive from Boston, a real gem of a place. It's not as big a time commitment as something like Yellowstone. Really easy to get around, whether by car, bike, or the shuttles run by NPS. Lots of hiking options and pure natural beauty. You can cover the main loop and Cadillac Mountain in one day, and make the longer loop to Bass Harbor if you like. Bar Harbor, ME is a pretty little town with some enjoyable food. It's not too hard to find accommodation nearby, even on short notice (about two weeks).

WOW! So much to see and do. Give yourself a few days so you can see it all! Accessible by car, trolley, free shuttle, bike, and foot. Don't forget Schoodic Peninsula is also part of Acadia NP and has some wonderful hiking trails and breathtaking scenery!

We stayed in midcoast Maine for a week, and drove to Acadia on Monday. It was pretty crowded for a Monday, we thought, until we realized (after circling for a space on Cadillac Mountain) that people had flocked there for the partial eclipse. We're still not sure why, as the viewing there isn't any better than anywhere else, but I guess to say you were on Cadillac during the eclipse. So, we were on Cadillac for the 2017 eclipse. lol. The scenery all through the park is gorgeous. If you can only go once, and you want to drive, take the Park Loop Road, and stop at all the places you can. If you want to take the loop only once, make sure you stop at Sand Beach, Thunder Hole, and all the others in the one-way section. We went back the following Friday, hiked up the Bubbles, visited Sand Beach, revisited Thunder Hole, and had a great time. If we go back some day, it would be great to take a carriage ride, maybe. The free shuttles from the Visitor Center are very convenient, although we didn't use them. The parking pass was $25, but it was good for a week, which is perfect for vacationers. Bar Harbor is 5 minutes away, with nice restaurants, shopping, etc. Great trip.
We love the National Parks and this one was a bit different than others but we climbed & hiked up mountains, saw the ocean and the most beautiful views on the cliffs.

Spent four days hiking the trails and walking on the carriage paths. Used the bus from the Hulls Visitor Center to get around and not have to worry about finding a place to park. Just a beautiful park and enjoyed every minute.

We recently went to Acadia as part of a tour group and we could have easily spent several days there. A group of us climbed the Pebble South Trail and it was quite challenging but offered spectacular views.
review_title: A must-see for lovers of the National Parks.

review_body: This is a must see and do when visiting Bar Harbor. Whether you are an avid hiker or a couch potato this is a must for everyone. The drive is breath-taking with pull-offs for some beautiful views. You don't have to hike any of the trails to enjoy the beauty of the park. Wear sensible shoes!!!!
review_title: An amazing drive with awesome views

review_body: Acadia NP is beautiful. The park roads and trails are laid out and maintained nicely, and there are lots of trails of different landscapes and of varying degrees of difficulty - flat trails, beaches, cliffs, steep hikes - At every turn, there's another beautiful scenic view worth photographing. Even though we visited in the busy season and came across small areas of congestion, we never felt overly crowded at any point in time. A must see if you are a park enthusiast.

I've visited here twice before, as a child and as a young adult, and don't remember it being quite so crowded. We toured the park loop road on a socked in, foggy, rainy, Saturday, and were still lucky to find parking at various hot spots. I can't imagine what it would be like on a clear and sunny day. The park now has sawhorses set up so that you can only park in designated areas. If you are on the one way loop road and cant find a spot to park, then you are out of luck. You can always take the bus tours, which may be a better option, but if you drive up there on vacation you feel more comfy in your own car. Once you get away from the popular spots it is less crowded, but if you are there to see a certain sight, best do so early in the a.m. or later in the evening when the crowds are gone. Highly recommend going up Cadillac Mountain on a moonless night. I have never seen such stars, even out west in NM and AZ where there is little light pollution. Bundle up, bring a flashlight, find a flat rock and lie down and watch the shooting stars and milky way. A definite must do if you have children.
great place - excellent routing of traffic - although people still are in a big hurry and drive way over limits. the one way traffic is great - will go back next year as there is so much to see here.
review_title: great - a place other parks should emulate

review_body: We took a tour round Acadia National Park, which took in the major views and stopped at Thunder Hole which was very popular with tourists, also the top of Cadillac Mountain where you got very good all round views. The tour guide was a local who was tremendously knowledgeable about the park and island, which made the day very enjoyable. I would love to return and spend longer here.

Such a wonderful place to visit!!Every day you could find a new and incredible trail,carriage road or pond to discoverBe aware that parking space is scarce and taking the bus for free from the Visitor's center could be an excellent option

Acadia National Park can be seen in a day or a week depending on what you like to do. If you ride your bike or take a hike choice of trails is numerous...a different trail every day. If you just want to drive the park loop and stop to see the major sites, we did it at a relaxed pace and took 6 hours to see everything we wanted to see.There are restrooms at every major stop and gift shops. Cadillac Mountain, Jordan Pond and Thunder Rocks are the highlights not to be missed.

Acadia NP has lots to explore. There are many trails to hike & areas to explore. We had a car but saw many using the free Island Explorer for transportation. We drove to the top of Cadillac Mountain & experienced the breathtaking views. Thunder Hole was great, very cool to see the ocean with the waves rushing in. We also did a Carriage horse ride which was amazing. If you drive, parking at some of the attractions can be a challenge especially close to Jordon Pond. We basically circled the parking lot until a free space opened up. Acadia is picture perfect!
Did the tour and it was very nice. Great views from Cadillac Mountain. Would highly recommend it. Very nice...

We hiked the shore path, marveling at the gorgeous vistas. The views from the top of Cadillac were spectacular. Biked the Witch Hole trail (my first time biking in about 40 years!) stopping along the way to enjoy the water lilies, etc. The hills were tough for me but I did them! Made it a point to hike the Jesup Trail from the Wild Gardens of Acadia. We love the board walk through the woods.
review_title: Two perfectly clear days of beauty!

review_body: This is a fabulous park there is nothing not to like about this area. It is breathtaking beautiful. I can say nothing negative and not to worry about parking for they have an island explorer that will take you wherever you want to go. My favorite place was Thunder Hole. The shore, the cliffs the ocean color is amazing.

The Atlantic Ocean, Sand Beach, Thunder Hole, Otter Cliffs, Jordan Pond, The Bubbles, Eagle Lake, Bass Harbor Light, Somes Sound, Cadillac Mountain. Awesome hikes, outstanding views, wonderful scents of coastal Maine. I ask you, "What's not to love?" You must experience Acadia for yourself.
Great vacation. Beautiful scenery. A must do. Great hiking and walking. Really enjoyed Cadillac Mountain and the Park Loop Road as well as hiking the trails and carriage roads.

We loved this place on two previous visits but after two hours of bumper to bumper driving on the one way road through the park and an inability to park anywhere near any of the sights such as Thunder Hole, Jordan Pond or Cadillac Mountain we decided to leave and go to the Schoodic Penisula. This was 10 times worse than a trip to Disneyworld and left you feeling like you were just a statistic being herded through the park. Literally, you had to park after a half mile of cars parked end to end and walk back to see anything. The paths looked more like Manhattan than Acadia and this was on a Monday. Coach loads of tourists arriving by the minute. What would this gem look like on a weekend during the summer. Set up a lottery for a limited number of day passes each summer and you would return this wonderful place back to its former glory.

Spent 4 days exploring Acadia NP. For anyone who loves the outdoors, this park is a must. Beautiful views all over the park and too many hiking, biking trails to cover. Wonderful park staff. One ranger was especially helpful and nice, Jeremy. Really made the park visit special. Thanks!

Took a couple visits to see much of the park, especially Cadillac Mountain. First try was so fogged in, we had to turn around and head back down.. second attempt was met with a barricade and lot full sign. Third try was a winner as we went and hour before sunset and hung out until thunder went down. Jordan Pond was jammed and both lots were full. Sand Beach was stunning and not too crowded, probably because it's a bit off the beaten path.
When you live in or near a city, it is wonderful to get out and remember what nature is all about. The beauty of this National Park is a wonderful experience.

I would recommend anyone to tour this National Park. It is an amazing place and the cost is nominal to access it. You can stop at various places and easily walk trails. We saw whales just playing and extraordinary views.
